wiki.content: Written by Benny Andersson, Björn Ulvaeus & Stig Anderson, this song appeared on ABBA's 1975 self-titled album. According to the Mamma Mia Songfacts, ABBA's manager Stig Anderson would often come up with titles that singers Ulvaeus and Andersson would write lyrics around, and this is an example of that. The phrase "Mamma Mia" is an Italian saying that literally means "My Mother" and is used to express surprise. When released as a 45rpm single, In much of the world, the b-side was "Intermezzo No. 1", an instrumental mostly played by Benny & Bjorn. In the UK, the b-side was "Tropical Loveland", a more straight-foward pop song. The song made in the top 10 in Australia, Belgium, UK, Germany and several places, but peaked at #32 on the US charts. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License and may also be available under the GNU FDL.
wiki.summary: Written by Benny Andersson, Björn Ulvaeus & Stig Anderson, this song appeared on ABBA's 1975 self-titled album. According to the Mamma Mia Songfacts, ABBA's manager Stig Anderson would often come up with titles that singers Ulvaeus and Andersson would write lyrics around, and this is an example of that. The phrase "Mamma Mia" is an Italian saying that literally means "My Mother" and is used to express surprise.

track.name: Mamma Mia
comments: Just to explain: ABBA recorded an LP of songs sung in Spanish, using the existing backing-tracks of the English-language versions. The album was called "Gracias Por La Musica".  After this they issued a few additional tracks in Spanish. All of these tracks currently appear on the album "ABBA Oro".
Close to 40 years later and still refreshing!
I was about to sing along but got thrown off when the lyrics were from another language. Still, I find the track incredibly catchy.
Wish I understood the language................thanx last.fm
and I don't like the movie.
